en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can define lower bounds and distinguish it from best cases.
en.Slide 2: The lower bound of an algorithm indicates the least amount of a resource that the algorithm needs for a problem of size $n$.
en.Slide 3: So what is the lower bound of the sequencial search algorithm?
en.Slide 4: In the best case of the algorithm, only a single element is investigated. $T(n) = 1$
en.Slide 5: Accordingly, the lowest growth rate (lower bound) of the algorithm in the best case is $\Omega(1)$.
en.Slide 6: In the worst case of the algorithm, $n$ elements are investigated. $T(n) = n$
en.Slide 7: Accordingly, the lowest growth rate (lower bound) of the algorithm in the worst case is $\Omega(n)$.
en.Slide 8: In the average case of the algorithm, $\lceil\frac{n}{2}\rceil$ elements are investigated. $T(n) = \frac{1}{2}n$
en.Slide 9: Accordingly, the lowest growth rate (lower bound) of the algorithm in the average case is also $\Omega(n)$ since we ignore constant terms.
